Totalitarianism and Terror
Totalitarianism is not merely a dictatorship. It is a form of government that seeks total domination over the individual and society. It differs from older forms of tyranny in its use of terror not as a means to an end, but as the very essence of its rule.
Terror becomes the executing agent of the laws of movement of history or nature. In a totalitarian regime, the law is not a stable framework for human action, but a dynamic force that must be realized through constant motion. The aim is to eliminate all spontaneity, all unpredictability, all human plurality.
The camp is the laboratory of totalitarianism. There, the experiment of total domination is carried out to its logical conclusion: the destruction of the juridical person, the moral person, and finally, the individuality of the human being. The victim is reduced to a bundle of reactions, stripped of all dignity and agency.
Ideology and Solitude
Totalitarian movements depend on ideology – the logic of an idea. The idea is treated as a premise from which everything else follows with necessary consistency, regardless of reality. The 'ice-cold reasoning' of the ideologue is appealing to the isolated masses who have lost their place in the world.
Loneliness is the common ground for terror. Not solitude, which is the dialogue of the two-in-one, of thinking. But loneliness, where one is deserted by all others and cannot even keep company with oneself. Totalitarianism thrives on this loneliness, organizing the masses not by integrating them, but by pressing them together, destroying the space between them that makes freedom possible.

The Banality of Evil
When I speak of the banality of evil, I do not mean to suggest that the crimes of the Holocaust were commonplace or that the perpetrators were not responsible. I mean that the evil we faced was not the result of a wicked or demonic will, but of a terrifying thoughtlessness.
Adolf Eichmann was not a monster in the traditional sense. He was a bureaucrat, a 'joiner', a man whose main concern was his career and his social status. He spoke in clichés, he thought in clichés. He was unable to think from the standpoint of someone else. It was this sheer thoughtlessness – which by no means acts as a stupid person – that predisposed him to become one of the greatest criminals of that period.
Thinking and Judgment
This leads to the question: Can thinking be a safeguard against evil? If evil is not radical, but banal – like a fungus that spreads on the surface – then perhaps the activity of thinking, the habit of examining whatever happens to come to pass or to attract attention, regardless of results and specific content, could condition men against evildoing.
Thinking is the dialogue of the self with itself. It requires solitude, but it is the prerequisite for judgment. Judgment is the ability to tell right from wrong, beautiful from ugly. In times of crisis, when the old rules no longer apply, the ability to judge for oneself, without relying on established norms, becomes crucial.

The Public and the Private Realm
The distinction between the public and the private realm, roughly corresponding to the distinction between the political and the household, is a key element in understanding the human condition. The rise of the social realm, which is neither private nor public, has blurred this distinction, leading to a confusion of categories that threatens the very possibility of meaningful political action.
In the ancient world, the private realm was the sphere of the household, of necessity, where the needs of life were attended to. The public realm was the sphere of freedom, where men (and alas, only men) could interact as equals, not ruled by necessity but by the desire for distinction and immortality through great deeds and words.
Today, we see the intrusion of necessity into the public sphere. Politics has become a matter of administration, of managing the economy, which is essentially housekeeping writ large. We have lost the sense of the public as a space for appearance, for the disclosure of who one is through action and speech.
Labor, Work, and Action
We must distinguish three fundamental human activities: labor, work, and action.
Labor corresponds to the biological process of the human body. The condition of labor is life itself. Labor leaves nothing behind; its products are consumed almost immediately. It is the cyclical, never-ending struggle against biological decay.
Work is the activity which corresponds to the unnaturalness of human existence, which is not embedded in the ever-recurring lifecycle of the species. Work provides an 'artificial' world of things, distinctly different from all natural surroundings. The condition of work is worldliness.
Action, the only activity that goes on directly between men without the intermediary of things or matter, corresponds to the human condition of plurality, to the fact that men, not Man, live on the earth and inhabit the world. While all aspects of the human condition are somehow related to politics, this plurality is specifically the condition – not only the conditio sine qua non, but the conditio per quam – of all political life.
The frailty of human affairs derives from the fact that we can never be sure of the outcome of our actions. One deed, and sometimes one word, suffices to change every constellation.
